subject: Re: [junit] Re: After I write my first testcase, I write 15 class make it run:-
msgSnippet: Isaac, J.B. s point is a good one--now that the code is written, concentrate on testing the non-UI model first.  If we had to do it again, given just the test
messageBody:
Isaac,

J.B.'s point is a good one--now that the code is written, concentrate on
testing the non-UI model first. If we had to do it again, given just
the test that you have written here, I could make it pass with

class View {
public void pressed(int floorNum, Direction direction) {
// do nothing
}
}

class Door {
boolean isOpen() {
return true;
}
}

This probably looks like cheating. It has two advantages--I now have a
working test suite (hooray!), and it helps me think of some more tests I
should write. Perhaps I would next write a test that forces me to write
code for pressed(), and then one that leads to a more interesting
implementation of isOpen.

David Saff

isaachanstar wrote:

> I'm very sorry for that I forget this important thing. Here is my
> first testcast:
> ____________________________________________________
> public void test_First_UP_Button_Pressed() {
> view.pressed(1, UP);
> assertTrue(firstDoor.isOpen());
> }
> ____________________________________________________
> here "view" is the Swing GUI interface.
>
> to make it run, i create Elevator, Door, Button class, and then, i
> create ElevatorModel to hold them all,
>
> and then, i create ElevatorView interface (i think i must separate
> model and view), and then, i create a
>
> Mockview class, this class is my first nightmare, too many swing api
> trouble me a lot. And then, i think
>
> "simulate elevator" should based on "events", so i create
> ElevatorArrivedListen, ButtonPressedListener,
>
> and ElevatorArrivedEvent, ButtonPressedListener. And then, i review my
> program -- one testcase and more
>
> then ten classes (interface).
>
> This is the descriptionof my program. Help gives me some advice, any
> sentence will help me, thanks.
>
>
>
>
>
